Class ec.meta.Deflector 

java.lang.Object
   |
   +----ec.meta.Deflector
public class Deflector
extends Object
A Deflector is an object which holds onto a Tether, and in general, deflects all method calls to one of the two variants of invoke() on a Tether. Many of the subclasses of Deflector are created automatically by the guest loader, but some are in fact created manually.

Deflector(Tether, Object)
Construct a new Deflector.

construct(StdCla, Tether, Object)
Construct a new deflector of the given Cla.
invoke(Deflector, Method, Object[])
This method does an invoke but transforms the result in the case of an exception: It turns BadInvokeExceptions into RuntimeExceptions (with a "shouldn't-happen" message), and throws the wrapped exceptions inside InvocationTargetExcpetions.
invokeRE(Deflector, Method, Object[])
This method is like the above invoke() but will only ever throw RuntimeExceptions (hence the "RE" in the name).
open(Deflector, Object)
Given a Deflector and a key, get it's target, but only if the key matches the Deflector's key; otherwise return null.
toString()
Override of method from java.lang.Object.

Deflector 
 public Deflector(Tether theTarget,
                  Object theKey)
Construct a new Deflector.

Parameters:
theTarget - the target of the Deflector
theKey - nullOk; the open key of the Deflector; a null key means the Deflector may not be opened

 public static Deflector construct(StdCla theCla,
                                   Tether theTarget,
                                   Object theKey)
Construct a new deflector of the given Cla.

Parameters:
theCla - the Cla of the deflector
theTarget - the target of the Deflector
theKey - nullOk; the open key of the Deflector; a null key means the Deflector may not be opened
Returns:
a new deflector
open 
 public static Tether open(Deflector deflector,
                           Object key)
Given a Deflector and a key, get it's target, but only if the key matches the Deflector's key; otherwise return null. This isn't an instance method so as not to sully whatever interface might be supplied by a subclass--Deflectors are meant to be mostly transparent after all.

Parameters:
deflector - the Deflector
key - notNull; the key to try opening it with
Returns:
nullOk; the target of the deflector, or null if the key was invalid
invoke 
 public static Object invoke(Deflector obj,
                             Method meth,
                             Object args[]) throws Exception, Error
This method does an invoke but transforms the result in the case of an exception: It turns BadInvokeExceptions into RuntimeExceptions (with a "shouldn't-happen" message), and throws the wrapped exceptions inside InvocationTargetExcpetions. The method is intended to be used by method wrappers (e.g., the Object method wrappers in Deflector itself).

Parameters:
obj - the Deflector to invoke on
meth - the method to invoke
args - the args to pass to the method
Returns:
s the result value of the invocation
Throws: Exception
thrown if the invocation causes an exception
Throws: Error
thrown if the invocation throws an Error
invokeRE 
 public static Object invokeRE(Deflector obj,
                               Method meth,
                               Object args[])
This method is like the above invoke() but will only ever throw RuntimeExceptions (hence the "RE" in the name). All other exceptions turn into a "shouldn't-happen" RuntimeException. The method is intended to be used by method wrappers (e.g., the Object method wrappers in Deflector itself).

Parameters:
obj - the Deflector to invoke on
meth - the method to invoke
args - the args to pass to the method
Returns:
s the result value of the invocation
Throws: RuntimeException
thrown if the invocation causes an exception
